dataset.title: Measurements of Soil pH and Soil Cations Along an Elevational Gradient

creator.organizationName: Coweeta Long Term Ecological Research Program

address.deliveryPoint: Daniel B. Warnell School of Forestry and Natural Resources

abstract.para: This project is part of a larger examination of site productivity along an elevational gradient. Soil pH was measured at each site. A subset of soil samples were analyzed for soil cations, e.g., K, Ca, Mg, and PO4-P, at each of the five terrestrial gradient plots located at Coweeta Hydrologic Lab, Otto, NC.

section.title: Soil Sample Collections
section.para: Soil cores were randomly collected along four different transects at each of the five terrestrial gradient sites, located at Coweeta Hydrologic Lab, Otto, NC. Transects were located in the original 20 × 40 m plots (plots were later expanded to 80 × 80 m). Soil cores were collected at a depth of 0-10 cm. Soils were wet sieved (<6 mm) before being air dried. Dried soils were then sieved a second time with a 2 mm sieve. We used the dilute double acid extraction method to measure soil cations (0-10 cm) collected during N mineralization measurements (5 g in 20 mL). Samples were analyzed using an atomic absorption spectrophotometer. Resulting data are presented in µg/g soil.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: CWT Study Site WS18 -- Watershed 18 in the Coweeta Basin, North Carolina, USA. Grady Branch Watershed. The first hydrologic records for this site began on 7/03/1936. The weir type for this watershed is a 120 degree V-notch. This is a control watershed that has been undisturbed since 1927.

CWT Study Site WS27 -- Watershed 27 in the Coweeta Basin, North Carolina, USA. Hard Luck Creek Watershed. The first hydrologic records from this watershed date to 11/02/1946. The weir is a 120 degree V notch. This a control watershed, but it was partially defoliated by fall cankerworm infestations from 1972 to 1979.

section.title: Soil pH and Cations at Terrestrial Gradient Sites
section.para: Please see http://coweeta.uga.edu/gradient_physical.html for description of plot characteristics

Soil cores were randomly collected along four different transects at each of the five terrestrial gradient sites, located at Coweeta Hydrologic Lab, Otto, NC. Transects were located in the original 20 × 40 m plots. Soil cores were collected at a depth of 0-10 cm. Soils were wet sieved to less than 6 mm before being air dried. Dried soils were then sieved a second time with a 2 mm sieve. We used the dilute double acid extraction method to measure soil cations collected during N mineralization measurements at 5 g in 20 mL. Samples were analyzed using an atomic absorption spectrophotometer. Resulting data are presented in µg/g soil.

abstract.para: The Coweeta LTER Research Program has evolved since 1980 from a site-based to a site- and region-based project examining the effects of disturbance and environmental gradients on biogeochemical cycling, and the underlying watershed ecosystem processes that regulate and respond to those cycles. The current interdisciplinary research integrates ecological and socioeconomic components across 54,000 km2 of the southern Appalachian Mountains, a biogeophysical and socioeconomic region in which evolutionary and historical processes converge (Whittaker 1956, Markusen 1987, Barnes 1991, Kretzschmar et al. 1993, Bailey 1996). Our research objective in 2002-2008 is to advance scientific understanding of the spatial, temporal, and decision-making components of land use and land-use change in the southern Appalachian Mountains over the last 200 years, and forecast patterns into the future 30 years. Our guiding hypothesis is that the frequency, intensity, and extent of land use represents human decision-making in response to socioeconomic and biogeophysical conditions with consequences that cascade through ecosystems.
